trans-unit.source: 3-D perspective effects for XAML UI
trans-unit.target: 3-D perspective effects for XAML UI

trans-unit.source: You can apply 3-D effects to content in your Windows Runtime apps using perspective transforms.
trans-unit.target: You can apply 3-D effects to content in your Windows Runtime apps using perspective transforms.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can create the illusion that an object is rotated toward or away from you, as shown here.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can create the illusion that an object is rotated toward or away from you, as shown here.

trans-unit.source: 3-D perspective effects for XAML UI
trans-unit.target: 3-D perspective effects for XAML UI

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: You can apply 3-D effects to content in your Windows Runtime apps using perspective transforms.
trans-unit.target: You can apply 3-D effects to content in your Windows Runtime apps using perspective transforms.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can create the illusion that an object is rotated toward or away from you, as shown here.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can create the illusion that an object is rotated toward or away from you, as shown here.

trans-unit.source: Image with Perspective Transform
trans-unit.target: Image with Perspective Transform

trans-unit.source: Another common usage for perspective transforms is to arrange objects in relation to one another to create a 3-D effect, as here.
trans-unit.target: Another common usage for perspective transforms is to arrange objects in relation to one another to create a 3-D effect, as here.

trans-unit.source: Stacking objects to create a 3-D effect
trans-unit.target: Stacking objects to create a 3-D effect

trans-unit.source: Besides creating static 3-D effects, you can animate the perspective transform properties to create moving 3-D effects.
trans-unit.target: Besides creating static 3-D effects, you can animate the perspective transform properties to create moving 3-D effects.

trans-unit.source: [Run this sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=236111) to see an example of this.
trans-unit.target: [Run this sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=236111) to see an example of this.

trans-unit.source: You just saw perspective transforms applied to images, but you can apply these effects to any [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911), including controls.
trans-unit.target: You just saw perspective transforms applied to images, but you can apply these effects to any [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911), including controls.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can apply a 3-D effect to an entire container of controls like this:
trans-unit.target: For example, you can apply a 3-D effect to an entire container of controls like this:

trans-unit.source: 3-D effect applied to a container of elements
trans-unit.target: 3-D effect applied to a container of elements

trans-unit.source: Here is the XAML code used to create this sample:
trans-unit.target: Here is the XAML code used to create this sample:

trans-unit.source: Here we focus on the properties of [**PlaneProjection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210192) which is used to rotate and move objects in 3-D space.
trans-unit.target: Here we focus on the properties of [**PlaneProjection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210192) which is used to rotate and move objects in 3-D space.

trans-unit.source: The next sample allows you to experiment with these properties and see their effect on an object.
trans-unit.target: The next sample allows you to experiment with these properties and see their effect on an object.

trans-unit.source: Run this sample
trans-unit.target: Run this sample

trans-unit.source: PlaneProjection class
trans-unit.target: PlaneProjection class

trans-unit.source: You can apply 3D effects can to any [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911), by setting the UIElement's [**Projection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.uielement.projection.aspx) property using a [**PlaneProjection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210192).
trans-unit.target: You can apply 3D effects can to any [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911), by setting the UIElement's [**Projection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.uielement.projection.aspx) property using a [**PlaneProjection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210192).

trans-unit.source: The **PlaneProjection** defines how the transform is rendered in space.
trans-unit.target: The **PlaneProjection** defines how the transform is rendered in space.

trans-unit.source: The next example shows a simple case.
trans-unit.target: The next example shows a simple case.

trans-unit.source: This figure shows what the image renders as.
trans-unit.target: This figure shows what the image renders as.

trans-unit.source: The x-axis, y-axis, and z-axis are shown as red lines.
trans-unit.target: The x-axis, y-axis, and z-axis are shown as red lines.

trans-unit.source: The image is rotated backward 35 degrees around the x-axis using the [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx) property.
trans-unit.target: The image is rotated backward 35 degrees around the x-axis using the [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx) property.

trans-unit.source: RotateX minus 35 degrees
trans-unit.target: RotateX minus 35 degrees

trans-unit.source: The [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) property rotates around the y-axis of the center of rotation.
trans-unit.target: The [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) property rotates around the y-axis of the center of rotation.

trans-unit.source: RotateY minus 35 degrees
trans-unit.target: RotateY minus 35 degrees

trans-unit.source: The [**RotationZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationz) property rotates around the z-axis of the center of rotation (a line that is perpendicular to the plane of the object).
trans-unit.target: The [**RotationZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationz) property rotates around the z-axis of the center of rotation (a line that is perpendicular to the plane of the object).

trans-unit.source: RotateZ minus 45 degrees
trans-unit.target: RotateZ minus 45 degrees

trans-unit.source: The rotation properties can specify a positive or negative value to rotate in either direction.
trans-unit.target: The rotation properties can specify a positive or negative value to rotate in either direction.

trans-unit.source: The absolute number can be greater than 360, which rotates the object more than one full rotation.
trans-unit.target: The absolute number can be greater than 360, which rotates the object more than one full rotation.

trans-unit.source: [Run this sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=236112) to experiment with different values for the [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx), [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy), and [**RotationZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationz) properties to see the effect.
trans-unit.target: [Run this sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=236112) to experiment with different values for the [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx), [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy), and [**RotationZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationz) properties to see the effect.

trans-unit.source: You can move the center of rotation by using the [**CenterOfRotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationx.aspx), [**CenterOfRotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationy), and [**CenterOfRotationZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationz) properties.
trans-unit.target: You can move the center of rotation by using the [**CenterOfRotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationx.aspx), [**CenterOfRotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationy), and [**CenterOfRotationZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationz) properties.

trans-unit.source: By default, the axes of rotation run directly through the center of the object, causing the object to rotate around its center.
trans-unit.target: By default, the axes of rotation run directly through the center of the object, causing the object to rotate around its center.

trans-unit.source: But if you move the center of rotation to the outer edge of the object, it will rotate around that edge.
trans-unit.target: But if you move the center of rotation to the outer edge of the object, it will rotate around that edge.

trans-unit.source: The default values for **CenterOfRotationX** and **CenterOfRotationY** are 0.5, and the default value for **CenterOfRotationZ** is 0.
trans-unit.target: The default values for **CenterOfRotationX** and **CenterOfRotationY** are 0.5, and the default value for **CenterOfRotationZ** is 0.

trans-unit.source: For **CenterOfRotationX** and **CenterOfRotationY**, values between 0 and 1 set the pivot point at some location within the object.
trans-unit.target: For **CenterOfRotationX** and **CenterOfRotationY**, values between 0 and 1 set the pivot point at some location within the object.

trans-unit.source: A value of 0 denotes one object edge and 1 denotes the opposite edge.
trans-unit.target: A value of 0 denotes one object edge and 1 denotes the opposite edge.

trans-unit.source: Values outside of this range are allowed and will move the center of rotation accordingly.
trans-unit.target: Values outside of this range are allowed and will move the center of rotation accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Because the z-axis of the center of rotation is drawn through the plane of the object, you can move the center of rotation behind the object using a negative number and in front of the object (toward you) using a positive number.
trans-unit.target: Because the z-axis of the center of rotation is drawn through the plane of the object, you can move the center of rotation behind the object using a negative number and in front of the object (toward you) using a positive number.

trans-unit.source: [**CenterOfRotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationx.aspx) moves the center of rotation along the x-axis parallel to the object while [**CenterOfRotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationy) moves the center or rotation along the y-axis of the object.
trans-unit.target: [**CenterOfRotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationx.aspx) moves the center of rotation along the x-axis parallel to the object while [**CenterOfRotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationy) moves the center or rotation along the y-axis of the object.

trans-unit.source: The next illustrations demonstrate using different values for **CenterOfRotationY**.
trans-unit.target: The next illustrations demonstrate using different values for **CenterOfRotationY**.

trans-unit.source: CenterOfRotationY = "0.5" (default)
trans-unit.target: CenterOfRotationY = "0.5" (default)

trans-unit.source: CenterOfRotationY equals 0.5
trans-unit.target: CenterOfRotationY equals 0.5

trans-unit.source: CenterOfRotationY = "0.1"
trans-unit.target: CenterOfRotationY = "0.1"

trans-unit.source: CenterOfRotationY equals 0.1
trans-unit.target: CenterOfRotationY equals 0.1

trans-unit.source: Notice how the image rotates around the center when the [**CenterOfRotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationy) property is set to the default value of 0.5 and rotates near the upper edge when set to 0.1.
trans-unit.target: Notice how the image rotates around the center when the [**CenterOfRotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationy) property is set to the default value of 0.5 and rotates near the upper edge when set to 0.1.

trans-unit.source: You see similar behavior when changing the [**CenterOfRotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationx.aspx) property to move where the [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) property rotates the object.
trans-unit.target: You see similar behavior when changing the [**CenterOfRotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationx.aspx) property to move where the [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) property rotates the object.

trans-unit.source: CenterOfRotationX = "0.5" (default)
trans-unit.target: CenterOfRotationX = "0.5" (default)

trans-unit.source: CenterOfRotationX equals 0.5
trans-unit.target: CenterOfRotationX equals 0.5

trans-unit.source: CenterOfRotationX = "0.9" (right-hand edge)
trans-unit.target: CenterOfRotationX = "0.9" (right-hand edge)

trans-unit.source: CenterOfRotationX equals 0.9
trans-unit.target: CenterOfRotationX equals 0.9

trans-unit.source: Use the [**CenterOfRotationZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationz) to place the center of rotation above or below the plane of the object.
trans-unit.target: Use the [**CenterOfRotationZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.centerofrotationz) to place the center of rotation above or below the plane of the object.

trans-unit.source: This way, you can rotate the object around the point analogous to a planet orbiting around a star.
trans-unit.target: This way, you can rotate the object around the point analogous to a planet orbiting around a star.

trans-unit.source: [Run this slider sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=236112) to experiment with rotating the object around different locations for the center of rotation.
trans-unit.target: [Run this slider sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=236112) to experiment with rotating the object around different locations for the center of rotation.

trans-unit.source: Positioning an object
trans-unit.target: Positioning an object

trans-unit.source: So far, you learned how to rotate an object in space.
trans-unit.target: So far, you learned how to rotate an object in space.

trans-unit.source: You can position these rotated objects in space relative to one another by using these properties:
trans-unit.target: You can position these rotated objects in space relative to one another by using these properties:

trans-unit.source: [**LocalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetx) moves an object along the x-axis of the plane of a rotated object.
trans-unit.target: [**LocalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetx) moves an object along the x-axis of the plane of a rotated object.

trans-unit.source: [**LocalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsety) moves an object along the y-axis of the plane of a rotated object.
trans-unit.target: [**LocalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsety) moves an object along the y-axis of the plane of a rotated object.

trans-unit.source: [**LocalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetz) moves an object along the z-axis of the plane of a rotated object.
trans-unit.target: [**LocalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetz) moves an object along the z-axis of the plane of a rotated object.

trans-unit.source: [**GlobalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetx) moves an object along the screen-aligned x-axis.
trans-unit.target: [**GlobalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetx) moves an object along the screen-aligned x-axis.

trans-unit.source: [**GlobalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsety) moves an object along the screen-aligned y-axis.
trans-unit.target: [**GlobalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsety) moves an object along the screen-aligned y-axis.

trans-unit.source: [**GlobalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetz) moves an object along the screen-aligned z-axis.
trans-unit.target: [**GlobalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetz) moves an object along the screen-aligned z-axis.

trans-unit.source: Local offset
trans-unit.target: Local offset

trans-unit.source: The [**LocalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetx), [**LocalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsety), and [**LocalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetz) properties translate an object along the respective axis of the plane of the object after it has been rotated.
trans-unit.target: The [**LocalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetx), [**LocalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsety), and [**LocalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetz) properties translate an object along the respective axis of the plane of the object after it has been rotated.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, the rotation of the object determines the direction that the object is translated.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, the rotation of the object determines the direction that the object is translated.

trans-unit.source: To demonstrate this concept, the next sample animates **LocalOffsetX** from 0 to 400 and [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) from 0 to 65 degrees.
trans-unit.target: To demonstrate this concept, the next sample animates **LocalOffsetX** from 0 to 400 and [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) from 0 to 65 degrees.

trans-unit.source: Run this sample
trans-unit.target: Run this sample

trans-unit.source: Notice in the preceding sample that the object is moving along its own x-axis.
trans-unit.target: Notice in the preceding sample that the object is moving along its own x-axis.

trans-unit.source: At the very beginning of the animation, when the [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) value is near zero (parallel to the screen), the object moves along the screen in the x direction, but as the object rotates toward you, the object moves along the x-axis of the plane of the object toward you.
trans-unit.target: At the very beginning of the animation, when the [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) value is near zero (parallel to the screen), the object moves along the screen in the x direction, but as the object rotates toward you, the object moves along the x-axis of the plane of the object toward you.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, if you animated the **RotationY** property to -65 degrees, the object would curve away from you.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, if you animated the **RotationY** property to -65 degrees, the object would curve away from you.

trans-unit.source: [**LocalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsety) works similarly to [**LocalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetx), except that it moves along the vertical axis, so changing [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx) affects the direction **LocalOffsetY** moves the object.
trans-unit.target: [**LocalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsety) works similarly to [**LocalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetx), except that it moves along the vertical axis, so changing [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx) affects the direction **LocalOffsetY** moves the object.

trans-unit.source: In the next sample, **LocalOffsetY** is animated from 0 to 400 and **RotationX** from 0 to 65 degrees.
trans-unit.target: In the next sample, **LocalOffsetY** is animated from 0 to 400 and **RotationX** from 0 to 65 degrees.

trans-unit.source: Run this sample
trans-unit.target: Run this sample

trans-unit.source: [**LocalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetz) translates the object perpendicular to the plane of the object as though a vector was drawn directly through the center from behind the object out toward you.
trans-unit.target: [**LocalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.localoffsetz) translates the object perpendicular to the plane of the object as though a vector was drawn directly through the center from behind the object out toward you.

trans-unit.source: To demonstrate how **LocalOffsetZ** works, the next sample animates **LocalOffsetZ** from 0 to 400 and [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx) from 0 to 65 degrees.
trans-unit.target: To demonstrate how **LocalOffsetZ** works, the next sample animates **LocalOffsetZ** from 0 to 400 and [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx) from 0 to 65 degrees.

trans-unit.source: Run this sample
trans-unit.target: Run this sample

trans-unit.source: At the beginning of the animation, when the [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx) value is near zero (parallel to the screen), the object moves directly out toward you, but as the face of the object rotates down, the object moves down instead.
trans-unit.target: At the beginning of the animation, when the [**RotationX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationx) value is near zero (parallel to the screen), the object moves directly out toward you, but as the face of the object rotates down, the object moves down instead.

trans-unit.source: Global offset
trans-unit.target: Global offset

trans-unit.source: The [**GlobalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetx), [**GlobalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsety), and [**GlobalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetz) properties translate the object along axes relative to the screen.
trans-unit.target: The [**GlobalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetx), [**GlobalOffsetY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsety), and [**GlobalOffsetZ**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetz) properties translate the object along axes relative to the screen.

trans-unit.source: That is, unlike the local offset properties, the axis the object moves along is independent of any rotation applied to the object.
trans-unit.target: That is, unlike the local offset properties, the axis the object moves along is independent of any rotation applied to the object.

trans-unit.source: These properties are useful when you want to simply move the object along the x-, y-, or z-axis of the screen without worrying about the rotation applied to the object.
trans-unit.target: These properties are useful when you want to simply move the object along the x-, y-, or z-axis of the screen without worrying about the rotation applied to the object.

trans-unit.source: The next sample animates [**GlobalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetx) from 0 to 400 and [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) from 0 to 65 degrees.
trans-unit.target: The next sample animates [**GlobalOffsetX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.globaloffsetx) from 0 to 400 and [**RotationY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.media.planeprojection.rotationy) from 0 to 65 degrees.

trans-unit.source: Run this sample
trans-unit.target: Run this sample

trans-unit.source: Notice in this sample that the object does not change course as it rotates.
trans-unit.target: Notice in this sample that the object does not change course as it rotates.

trans-unit.source: That is because the object is being moved along the x-axis of the screen without regard to its rotation.
trans-unit.target: That is because the object is being moved along the x-axis of the screen without regard to its rotation.

trans-unit.source: Positioning an object
trans-unit.target: Positioning an object

trans-unit.source: You can use the [**Matrix3DProjection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210128) and [**Matrix3D**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243266) types for more complex semi-3D scenarios than are possible with the [**PlaneProjection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210192).
trans-unit.target: You can use the [**Matrix3DProjection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210128) and [**Matrix3D**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243266) types for more complex semi-3D scenarios than are possible with the [**PlaneProjection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210192).

trans-unit.source: **Matrix3DProjection** provides you with a complete 3D transform matrix to apply to any [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911), so that you can apply arbitrary model transformation matrices and perspective matrices to elements.
trans-unit.target: **Matrix3DProjection** provides you with a complete 3D transform matrix to apply to any [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911), so that you can apply arbitrary model transformation matrices and perspective matrices to elements.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind that these API are minimal and therefore if you use them, you will need to write the code that correctly creates the 3D transform matrices.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind that these API are minimal and therefore if you use them, you will need to write the code that correctly creates the 3D transform matrices.

trans-unit.source: Because of this, it is easier to use **PlaneProjection** for simple 3D scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Because of this, it is easier to use **PlaneProjection** for simple 3D scenarios.
